key_title: Key to the species of Boronia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Rutaceae

source.author: Duretto, M.F.
source.title: Rutaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Duretto, M.F. (1999). Rutaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves strongly discolorous, abaxial surface with dense, velvety, off-white indumentum of stellate hairs; petals valvate, with obviously raised midrib on the abaxial surface; rare, in East Gippsland
Leaves not or slightly discolorous, stellate hairs absent, indumentum never velvet- like; petals imbricate, without obvious raised midrib; widespread
Sepals much smaller than petals, leaves subterete to terete; western Victoria, mostly mallee areas
Sepals slightly smaller to slightly longer than petals; leaves plane; western to eastern Victoria, mainly in swampy sites
Leaflets obovate; inflorescence terminal; petals valvate; high altitude sites above 600 m
Leaflets narrow-ellptic to narrow obovate or oblong; inflorescence axillary; near-coastal and foothill forest below 600 m altitude
Longest leaflets less than 10 mm long, margins distinctly serrulate
Longest leaflets greater than 10 mm long, margins smooth to slightly serrulate
Style densely pilose, almost hidden by large stigma
Style glabrous or pilose, not hidden by small stigma
Leaves, ovary and fruit hispidulous; plant strongly lemon-scented; Eastern Highlands and Snowfields
Leaves, ovary and fruit glabrous; western Victoria
Leaflets less than 2 mm wide, terete or subterete (sandy heath and mallee of Little and Big Deserts)
Leaflets 2–7 mm wide, plane (mostly moist forest and woodlands of the Grampians)
